commentBody: I think egocentric model may be one the more enjoyable answers in a long long while.

The dressmaker's new creations were the talk of the gown.

(I've used A-line like that before.)

A reprise of one of my all-time favorite answers!

2 results for ZOLAESQUE from Modern Era puzzles:

Sun Nov 23, 2025	
72D	
Reminiscent of a certain French author's work	
Trenton Charlson	

Fri Nov 20, 2009	
4D	
√Ä la the founder of literary naturalism	
Alan Olschwang

Gamgee Paseo... No idea that "e" was the missing letter. Liked the wiley coyote clue the best. Whether this puzzle was someone's first or thirty eighth  one doesnt matter to me, as such a fact neither adds or subtracts from the solving experience. But the other puns were pretty funny too.

The themers were very funny, Trenton! And I don't think there was too much EXOTICA in the fill. Hope all have a good time.

Waiting for commenters to come up with more themers (which will not have to cross anything).

Wow, you had me at SPANISHRAMADA. This is probably my vote for puzzle of the year. Not just for the theme, which was funny, complex, witty and had no duds at all. But just look at the rest of the fill. You had seven great long themes like this and still had room for two great 14 letter additional entries? Right next to ZOLAESQUE and SUCCEEDED? Are you kidding me? Very little glue, clever clues, perfect amount of challenge, I have nothing but praise and amazement for this one. Only disappointment‚Äîwould it be too much to ask ‚Äúringmaster‚Äù to clue to FRODO in a puzzle with Sam GAMGEE?

(Second try. Changed a word.)


The EGOCENTRIC MODEL was having a terrible month.  

She was supposed to do a photo shoot at a SPANISH RAMADA, but the promised OCTILLION DRESSES were nowhere near - a million at best.

Next she was to appear on an episode of DANCING WITH THE TSARS, but Alexandra Feodorovna made her use the LESSER OF TWO VEILS for her big scene, and ruined it.

Finally, she was introducing a new wellness nectar to her followers, but when she poured a glass on TikTok, what came out was an unappetizing UNCLEAR POTION.

What to do??  ACME TO THE RESCUE! Her agent ordered a package of Acme brand dehydrated potion clearance tablets (with added vitamin E) and she was able to make a new TikTok, as well as more money promoting the tablets.
A very fun puzzle!  I love the wittiness of the long answers.  I only had one wee cheat, caught by careful perusal of the answer pdf.  I had 'oxy' for 'OXO'...yes, my crossing answer made no sense!
It is a puzzle like this that first made me love doing crosswords. Each theme answer made me chuckle. The entire grid was a joy!
early signs are that we liked this one! Let's see if it holds.

Another of those puzzles you can hop around in and the fills you skipped over emerge.  I was delighted when puns started jumping out, ENAMORed by every one, and laughing out loud that you could SQUEEZE so many in.  

This was a honey of a puzzle, Trenton, just right for a Sunday.  Thank you.

Yes. A thinking person‚Äôs Sunday. 

Thanks, Trenton.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/11/22/sunday-november-23-2025/#ny
Oh man‚Ä¶ loved this one. Great clues and fun entries. Well done and thank you.

Very amusing and some great cluing. 

Hard to think of other examples and I haven't tried Trenton's three other examples in his notes yet. Hmmm:

[What is required to make a lot of syrup?]
MAPLE RESOURCES

I see this one has a full alphabet too, what are those called again, pangrams? Someone was complaining yesterday that having two pangrams in a puzzle was virtuoso but came at the expense of a good fill. But when someone is the champion Scrabble player of Ohio, he can make it look easy!

A thoroughly amusing theme. DANCING WITH THE TSARS is brilliant. 

I especially like ZOLAESQUE.  'Z' was my final entry after thinking of the suffix for CIVIL. 

Nice twin clue and proximity of POST ITS and NOTES [Little reminders]. 

Thanks, Trenton, that was fun.  It reminded me of a lovely vase I bought in Athens with a deer engraving. I call it ‚ÄúDoe on a Grecian urn‚Äù.
Triangle before LANGUAGE at 2D
This was fun! Thanks, Trenton! Happy Sunday, y‚Äôall!!

Today I learned that PASEO is recognized as an English word. I knew it from Spanish and saw that it fit, but I resisted it until proven overwhelmingly by the crosses because the clue did not suggest the answer would be a foreign word. So I looked it up in Merriam-Webster, and there it is! Another of the many Spanish loanwords English.

Loved the puzzle, by the way, especially DANCING WITH THE TSARS.

I am shocked at these stats!

Global Stats
Difficulty  Very Hard
Median Solve Time  26:07
Median Solver  24% slower
‚ö°28% of users solved faster than their Sunday average.
5% solved much faster (>20%) than their Sunday average.
üê¢72% of users solved slower than their Sunday average.
53% solved much slower (>20%) than their Sunday average.

Regarding those OCTILLIONDRESSES being "billions and billions of boutique items," I would note that it takes an awful lot of billions to make an octillion--in fact (in the American system for large-number nomenclature) a quintillion of 'em!
Great puzzle. Let's hope Trenton Charlson doesn't take another five year break until we see the next one.

Happy puzzle mania day.  Receiving the NYT puzzle mania always improves my November.

Sunday‚Äôs puzzle was breezy and brightened by the letter switching gimmick.  I admit to missing the trick in ACMETOTHERESCUE and to not seeing the second switch (POTION/option) in UNCLEARPOTION, despite the hint in the clue.  I did get DANCINGWITHTHETSARS without crosses, and LESSEROFTWOVEILS with only a few.  Last to fall was my favorite, OCTILLIONDRESSES, which was complicated by my failure to recognize PASEO, until, of course, it came to me INAFLASH

(Inspired by the theme):


One of my favorite parts of ‚ÄúAlice In Wonderland‚Äù is the vanishing act.





(Et tu, emu)

I must admit that sometimes I scoff at people (including at myself) who complain that their comment has been emu‚Äôd.  But, but, still, I‚Äôm a little bummed.  Here‚Äôs an abbreviated version.

This would almost (sorta, kinda, not really) work if only there were a famous ode to Spoonerisms.

‚ÄúBest Oklahoman expressions?‚Äù / TOP SOONERISMS.

Great to see Trenton Charlson.  Hard to believe it‚Äôs been almost 5 years.  So many elegant entries in addition to the clever themers.  TRIASSIC PERIOD, PERSIMMON, ZOLAESQUE . . .
  Delightful puzzle.

Whenever I see ZOLAESQUE, I‚Äôm reminded of the scene of the finals of the Stamford Crossword tournament in the documentary Wordplay when Trip Payne exclaims ‚ÄúOh, Good God!‚Äù when he finally deciphers it (then clued as [Stark and richly detailed, as writing]).


Counting today, it‚Äôs only happened once, but that‚Äôs something.

I am in a real slump.

The second day in a row I just struggled and muttered and complained about how I couldn't get two answers next to each other that I was confident in.

I stared forever at first three letter of 28A.  Finally settled on the correct answer of OCTILLION DRESSES.  Had I saw that "cotillion dresses" would be the corresponding trick word, I would have been confident.  But I didn't and I wasn't, and I could not find my error.

So I accepted the blue (again), and it turns out the only error I had was nowhere near where I was looking:  116A I had EeSES rather than ESSES. 

Maybe I need a break.  I've had less fun this week than ever with crosswords, and I'm getting to dread when the puzzle drops.

I thought it was an decently constructed puzzle, but it was like walking through waist-deep muck.  And anticlimactic to only get a blue star.

God how I pity me.
A celebrated weasel might be the STOAT OF THE TOWN.

whoever said that sundays have a moh-rating of 5 or 6 should have a go at this gem.
sheesh.  a 9 for me.

As soon as I saw the first themed clue I realized the trick today would be about groaners. That always demotivates me. I just don't find dad-joke-level wordplay funny ü§∑üèΩ

Parts of the puzzle seemed Monday-easy. However, in places the grid resisted me, and not being in the mood to struggle with it I just checked it, and then enabled autocheck.

Personally I didn't like this at all. That being said, it probably wasn't a bad puzzle, unlike yesterday's. I just didn't vibe with it at all.

Come to think of it, I think I know what irked me most. I can't stand John Kugelman grids. His themes are almost always groany, and his fill invariably stumps me. For some reason, the editors love him. He's had, what? 20 Sunday puzzles over two years? Way too many, whatever the exact number is. Anyway - the first thing I do when I open a Sunday puzzle is check whether it's not a Kugelman. If it's not, I sigh with relief. Today I got a Kugelman from Trenton Charlson... I dared hope I would have fun and I was let down üò¢
A fiasco is bigger than a SNAFU.

An excellent Sunday puzzle. üëèüëè

OPART was dooking me for a while but the typo was elsewhere. 

TESH, GAMGEE, TRISHA, NOE, DIDI were unknowns but getable from crosses 

Many thanks.
Clever, fun and a bit quicker than my usual Sunday.
RAMADA branded hotels in Europe are as rare as üé†üí© but the anagram was good.
I would watch DANCING WITH THE TSARS for the outfits alone.

Anyone else think that "IN A FLASH" is an adverb and not an adjective? So "very quickly" would have been a better clue than "very fast"?

I guess the ship has long since sailed on adverbs and adjectives though. I'd better think smarter from now on.
Weak theme, mostly inoffensive cluing but just never really got on the puzzle's wavelength. Onwards!

Could someone please explain 2 down to me.  I have never heard the phrase Love Language.  I also have a problem with the clue for 4 down.  Paseo is a Spanish word, and nothing in the clue indicates a Spanish answer.  On top of that, paseo just means a walk, or a stroll and is not necessarily an evening stroll.
Well, that was fun!  Great themers and nice fill all around.  Even with all of the theme material, we still got TRIASSIC PERIOD, ZOLAESQUE, MADAME TUSSAUDS and PERSIMMON.

I found this puzzle challenging, but enjoyable after yesterday's slog.

I was about to embarrass myself by asking about 117A, BASE the corner of a diamond? ü§î The penny has just dropped. Baseball strikes again! I really should remember that meaning of diamond by now. üôÑ

Oh, so good to see Trenton back after a long absence. He was prolific for a period, with nine puzzles in 2019, and eight in both 2020 and 2021.  I love his craftsmanship and the high bar he sets. 

Look at today‚Äôs puzzle.  Sure, it‚Äôs easy to find words that become other words when you flip the first two letters, if they‚Äôre short.  Even in today‚Äôs puzzle there are non-theme words that do that ‚Äì ACT, IRA, NOE, EMTS, USB, AWS, REN, ITT.

But try coming up with longer ones like Trenton did, i.e. RAMADA, COTILLION, OPTION, and GEOCENTRIC.  How did he do that?  Wow!

Then he had to make phrases including those words, phrases that fit symmetry, that is, the seven theme answers had to include three pairs of entries, each with the same number of letters.  Double wow!

And, for me, there was more to love.  Lovely answers (MIFF, ACCURSE, FINITE, ZOLAESQUE, MADAME TUSSAUDS, PERSIMMON), a sweet dook (REDANT), a TIL (HEAVE TO), and a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (STRAP).

I started this puzzle with a smile, Trenton, when I saw your name, and ended it the same way after a splendid outing.  Thank you, and please, don‚Äôt be a stranger!

Really enjoyed that. Hit the theme with SPANISH RAMADA, the Armada being History 101 for us Brits. The hardest to work out was 28A as Cotillion is unknown, but I guess it‚Äôs the equivalent of the Debutantes presentation to the Palace? Fortunately long since ditched, *cue general grumbling about class structure, to the tune of God Save The Queen by the S** Pistols*

Where was I? Oh, the grid. Yes, there was rather a lot of three letter glue, but any puzzle that has Sam GAMGEE, absolutely the (working class) Hero of LOTR gets my vote.

Happy that it was a straightforward Sunday, as we‚Äôre rather suffering the after effects of a splendid company Christmas party on Friday. Yes, I know that‚Äôs two days ago, but hangovers don‚Äôt improve with age.

Loved loved this puzzle. Fresh and delightful. 
Thank you!
A joy to do.
‚ÄúMany‚Äù a Yeshiva student? Who else would there be in a Yeshiva?

Trenton Charlson once made a puzzle in which the only vowel in the answers was the letter I.  I mention this because it gives me an excuse to bring up a 1994 Sunday by Cathy Allis in which the only vowel was E, and which had one of my favorite puzzle titles of all time:

ELAND.

I started at the top middle, which gave me the last three letters of the first theme answer, -ADA. My brain immediately went to SPANISH ARMADA, probably because it's one of the very few dates in history that for some reason is imbedded in my brain, along with the Magna Carta and the erstwhile Columbus Day (because it's my birthday, or was until they made it a Monday holiday). It also helped that I had just glanced at the title. So I knew where this theme was going.

I really enjoyed the theme answers and, contrary to a lot of people here, found the puzzle pretty easy, aided by title being a big giveaway for me. The only theme answer that tripped me up for a tiny bit was LESSER OF TWO _____. Initially, I wrote in LESSER OF TWO VILES. I was thinking of some of those awful bridesmaid's dresses I had to wear in days of yore!
Has anyone solved the Bonus clues from Trenton?!?

Just my kind of Sunday ‚Äî two weeks in a row!

That is, lots of fresh, easy fill (tougher than last week in that regard, but still gentle enough for a casual, bleary-eyed Sunday morning solve) and a theme consisting of nothing more than goofy phrases.

Anyway, time for yoga!

Asking (begging) contributors to include the A 0r D Clue # in your posts.
It really makes it so much easier and faster to find the clue or answer that you are discussing.
Thanks and Happy Thanksgiving.

Someone who got you in a heap of trouble?

SUED CAR DEALER


(My fave was the ‚Äúlesser veils‚Äù one.)
This might be my favorite puzzle ever.

Whew. And Wow! Typical slow start for me, but finally tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point and just had a lot of fun working the crosses until each of the theme answers dawned on me. Had to have been quite a workout to come up with so many theme answers that fit the trick. Two thumbs up. And.. puzzle find today. Might have done this one, but of course didn't remember it. Anyway - a Tuesday from December 6, 2022 by Ross Trudeau and Wyna Liu. Not a huge trick and all straightforwardly clued, but thought it was quite impressive to come up with a string of theme answers that all fit the pattern: INAGARTEN IDABWELLS ADALOVELACE ANADEARMAS AVADUVERNAY EVAMENDES EVEENSLER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/6/2022&g=29&d=A ...

This was pretty fun once you get the trick but for my part I found it fairly hard for a Sunday puzzle, closer to an end of week one maybe. But maybe my brain just wasn't clicking today with some of the clues.

[Hide-and-seek in an old Victorian home, say]



A GAME OF NICHES
I realized I got my Lovelaces mixed up when LINDA didn't fit. üò≥

Haven't seen this byline in a while--I believe his last puzzle was seen in the TRIASSIC PERIOD!  Welcome back, Trenton Charlson :0)

I stared at the SPANISH RAMADA and, unenlightened, soldiered on...  It was DANCING WITH THE TSARS the tipped me off.  The most difficult to untangle was the 79A themer, but all of them were fun...and unexpected!  There was even a "double-whammy"!

Nice start to the day...  doing some T'giving prep today.  Already made the cornbread...speaking of which, David Connell always liked that recipe for "corn pone," but we haven't seen him here in a long while.  (I recently heard from "PecanTart"...who is also MIA nowadays.  Sigh.)

Okay, to all who are braving the highways, rails, skies, and waters-- stay safe!

Took me too long to realize that MADAME was not MADAM, and then to correctly spell  TUSSAUDS.

Got SPANISHRAMADA instantly, but didn't understand the theme until ACMETOTHERESCUE. (That's assuming I even fully understand the theme; I'm about to read the column to see if I've missed something.)

Did realize UNCLEARPOTION came from "nuclear option", but have no idea why this themer has two transpositions rather than one.

Hoping to discover that there is more to the theme than I realized. In any case, I solved this one without help in about 40 minutes.

I wonder if anyone else screwed up the northeast corner by putting in tEnD for 18D. I had the E and the D, so it seemed pretty logical.

So then I have tOoTRUE which kind of makes sense, but then 12D is AoO_EN and all I could think of was the Australian Open. 

So 25A is SnEp??? I don't think so!

Being up is one thing, the caffeine kicking in is another.

I went through all the comments in search of enlightenment but nobody seems to have had the same problem.

Finally AWOKEN, I realized I had 18D all wrong. HOWTRUE!  SEEK and ye shall find. 

Otherwise, I am glad to see Trenton Charlson again. Who else is going to construct a puzzle with entries like MADAME TUSSAUDS and TRIASSIC PERIOD?

Loved the photo of the executed murderers at Madam Tussaudis, by the way.
Such fun! Dancing with the Tsars was my FAVE!
Liked this one a lot. As usual, I missed the point of half the themers, but really got a kick out of them after reading the column. Well done Trenton!
Wow! A fun puzzle but I found this one HARD for a Sunday! This easily could've been a Friday-Sat. puzzle. Oh well, maybe my brain wasn't awake yet. More coffee!
Hard‚Ä¶

Today's math puzzler:

If six dressmakers can make 4 dresses in 10 days, how long will it take a million dressmakers to make an octillion dresses?
Very clever theme. I really like it.

Clever, albeit inconsistent theme. Stick with either "second in commanding" the first word of the answer or the second word of the answer. 

Spanish RAmada

COtillion dresses

Crosswords - particularly Sundays - should be consistent. Spent too long asking myself what a PSanish ramada would be because I got OCtillion dresses fairly early through the cross clues, and continued to try to answer the theme cluse by swapping the first two letters of the answer phrase (because second in command means second letter swap...makes sense).

I suppose if I had gotten Spanish RAmada first, I would have spent my time swapping the first two letters of the SECOND word (again, second in command).

Because the theme title could apply either way: swap first two letters of first word, or swap first two letters of second word....maybe there should have been theme answers that swapped the second word for the first word....of the first letter of the second word with the second letter of the first word....see how clumsy it is when you don't stick to a consistently parsed theme?

This could have been a great puzzle...but to me it's just lazy if you can't stick to a specific and consistent theme.
Fun groaners.
Very inconsistent with very questionable obscure answers and/or made up phrases to fill the grid. This whole week has been sloppy puzzles.

Fun Sunday puzzle! Cute theme, which was enjoyable to fill in. Somehow this puzzle reminds me of one of the most ingenious sci-fi stories I've ever read: "The Angelic Angleworm" by Fredric Brown (1943). (Available at Internet Archive: https://archive.org/details/Unknown_v06n05_1943-02_slpn/page/n47/mode/2up .)

I don't know if it was a clerical error or what, but I was hired as a cruise director for the Spanish armada.

I knew something was wrong when I learned that our only guests were Florence Henderson and Charo. But it seemed exciting and new so I set a course for adventure.

I wonder where my good friend Gopher is now.
Never seen CRATE used in this way, but if it means a hunk of junk then it‚Äôs apt for this slog of a puzzle.

Started this one last night and finished up this morning. The light came on with DANCING WITH THE TSARS. [John in the Radio Hall of Fame] was an instant gimme if you watched the news in the last month with NBA on NBC returning and his iconic song Roundball Rock (your ear worm for today)‚Ä¶ https://youtu.be/Eba7iaDIihk?si=C8UBDMZW3mlty4P0 Even better is this skit on SNL with Jason Sudeikis (most recently of Ted Lasso fame)as John Tesh https://youtu.be/r-uSWAJd9GE?si=6i4e6eEqGoqcaLZK Enjoying the start of a relaxing week up in our recently purchased cabin in Flagstaff, Arizona. This puzzle was the perfect start to the week.

I‚Äôll be honest, confidently plopping in ASPERSE for 60A occupied more time to resolve than I‚Äôd like to admit‚Ä¶ (at one point I was even rationalizing how Tempe, AZ could be a potential locale for one facing indecision at 42D). Ah, the unparalleled curiosity that is the brain.

Far from accursed, this puzzle was a real peach to solve and a delightful way to kick off the Sunday!

This was all very interesting but I prefer birdwatching.
(no this is not a puzzle)

[Seize land?]

Take acre

The 2025 Super Mega has seemingly contradictory instructions:

1.  "Locate the four italicized clues, whose answers provide instructions to the contest.  Follow those instructions in the grid to reveal a word or phrase that is this year's solution."  (Page 7. of actual paper version.)

2.  "Slide out Page 11 for the clues to the Super Mega. After you‚Äôve finished the puzzle, remove one letter from each set of circled squares to spell a word. The letters you remove, from top to bottom, will form an appropriate two-word phrase."  (Guide to the 2025 Super Mega from Gameplay)
Loved this one! Though I had to break my own rule and reveal 3 squares. That's my worst performance to date, but this was so much fun that I didn't mind.

What‚Äôs not to like? I got the gold star with zero flyspecking and enjoyed noodling out the theme answers along the way. Also, a rare top to bottom solve. 

Even so, it was still crunchy enough to be a fun romp and not just putting in my time.
Found this one pretty difficult, had to resort to the column to save my streak
Departing NYT columnist Deb Amlen is referenced in one of today's Washington Post puzzles by Evan Birnholz. A worthy tribute.

Not easy for me, but very fun!! Once again my rudimentary Spanish skills ACMEd to the rescue in my toughest area with PASEO. I do not know it as an English word at all, but I was really struggling up there and finally thought of when we're in Utila and say we're going to go pasearing... Which is taking the golf cart up the point to look at the most raw part of the island.

Anyhow, I thought all of the theme answers were very funny. Not sure I could pick a FAVE... If pushed, maybe DANCINGWITHTHETSARS. 

I got the idea pretty quickly with SPANISHRAMADA but it still took a while to work out all the rest and the fill was interesting and tough for me.  

The jalopy clue took me forever. I'm familiar with it as a car, mostly from my love of Trixie Belden books, but didn't understand and still not sure I see how it relates to CRATE. According to my very limited search, sounds like there's a game called Jalopy that has crates in it... Or maybe the cars were called crates because they're dilapidated. Anyhow, if anyone cares to expound, I'd appreciate it. 

And apologies because I haven't looked through the comments yet to see if that got anyone else. I got it on the crosses, I just didn't understand it. 

Fun! Now I have to get to work because I have a big deadline coming up before Thanksgiving,  and it's conch time! Ha! I'm leaving that voice to text error in because it's an I'm using to me accidental Utila reference. üêö
My car is parked on NOE and I am drinking a PERSIMMON smoothie, does this still count as an unassisted solve?
Really fun theme, Trenton. Hopefully it won't such a long break until your next appearance.

Apparently I was not on the same wavelength as Trenton as this one seemed to be consistently harder than expected.  About 7% slower than average, so I guess not as hard as it seemed.  It took longer than expected for me to latch on to the theme, and it did help a little once I did.  Good theme.  Not understanding how "second in command" relates to the puzzle.  If there is an explanation in the column, it did not resonate with me.
CRATE held me back for the longest time, having confidently filled in LEMON for ‚ÄúJalopy.‚Äù

Just wondering:

I posted a comment questioning the aptness of the answer JEW as an appropriate answer for the Sunday puzzle. The comment generated a vigorous exchange of comments (up to 8), but then the entire ‚Äúdiscussion‚Äù was deleted. 

I do understand the sensitive nature of this discussion, and I appreciate the paper does not want to encourage inflammatory dialogue (especially in the puzzle section!), but I felt it was odd that the conversation was summarily deleted without an explanatory note. 

Open discussion is now more important than ever.

tc

Once I rethought the number of dresses, things went more smoothly. There are a lot of euphemisms for 'jalopy' and I was sure there must be at least one starting with t!

TIL the definitions for 'lithe' and SVELTE have more overlap than I'd thought. Didn't hold me up, but I was giving that one THEEYE for awhile.

The plays on the phrases were delightful.

An entire thread about the use of the answer at 74A was taken down, even though I'm not sure why the discussion of   a specific word from the puzzle's appropriateness was considered offensive.

I wrote one more comment that never got posted.  I kept checking back, and at one point the entire thread was gone.

So here it is again, redacted as necessary (good thing I save most posts before refreshing):


The point here is, of course, that using "JŒµœâ" as an adjective is only pejorative because of malicious intent.  And I would rather not have my demonym hijacked by bigots for nefarious reasons.

I'd rather call someone a good JŒµœâ than "a good JŒµœâish person."  The latter is clunky and silly.

I'd rather say that an observant JŒµœâ doesn't work on the Sabbath, rather than "an observant JŒµœâish person."

I'd rather say that a JŒµœâ knows what to call him or herself better than a non-JŒµœâish bigot.

And I'd also say that a JŒµœâ who insists upon substituting "JŒµœâish person" for all of the above is actually appeasing all of the intolerant, narrow-minded haters out there.  And it unfortunately does happen sometimes.

Though I did GOPAST my average time by 22 mins, I HELD on as I wondered, CANI really do this without any lookups? "Yes, you can, Sebastian", I thought. HOWTRUE that was because I SUCCEEDED!! Crossword CRED accrued. 

Let the AWS commence.
Fun Sunday, thanks !
The OP in the deleted thread about 74A mentioned being reminded of an earlier time. I was reminded of 1977... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DaPBhxXhprg
Loved "Dancing With The Tsars"...indeed, loved it all on this gorgeous autumn afternoon. Many thanks Trenton!
I like OCTILLION DRESSES, LESSER OF TWO VEILS, EXOTICA, and POSTITS then POSITS. Good Sunday!

Things would go faster if I could "get it" in order to "solve it" instead of the other way around! 
CZARS would not have worked. ü§™ 
Fun puzzle.
Very impressive! Doesn't feel forced or cutesy. Sadly even the wily constructor of this gem couldn't escape the ORCA.

Good chewy Sunday with a fun theme.
Don't have time to read the comments, but thought of a couple of word pairs for this treatment:
psy-ops/spy-ops
action/cation

Thanks, Trenton.
Please don‚Äôt wait five more years to produce your next puzzle, Mr. Charleson! That was fun and challenging!

Who wouldn't want to dance with the Tsar?: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fp4dtvf6FL8&list=RDFp4dtvf6FL8&start_radio=1 (OK, the video is a little grainy, but, hey, what do you expect from something that was filmed 413 years ago?

I‚Äôm hoping that Trenton knows not to play ACCURSE in a Scrabble tournament using the North American dictionary, which is what he plays with. Otherwise, challenge! :) (It‚Äôs good in the international dictionary).
Sequel to, " Dancing with the Tsars." Swings with the kings. ( No blue suede shoes allowed).

By tradition, the last of Rome's VII kings, Lucius Tarquinius "the Proud," was ousted in 509BCE, in a coup led by Lucius Collatinus, Publius Valerius, and Junius Brutus--the last, a distant ancestor of the Brutus who conspired to overthrow Julius Caesar ("Et tu, Brute?"); in fact, the latter Brutus' participation in the conspiracy was seen as somewhat symbolic. 

So, after 509, Rome never had a king again. Even after the effective power of government passed from the Senate to the Emperor, and the republic transitioned into the Principate, Rome never had a king.

No, no kings.
What are the answers to the final three clues at the bottom?

Curious about other opinions. When does the experience of self, cross over into egocentrism? We each have individual needs and to different degrees. Is it strictly the motivation of action? Kind of an old argument, but doesn‚Äôt volunteer work become egocentric because it makes us feel good?

@Francis
The crosswords are for your pleasure.  Solve them any way that works for you and just enjoy spending some time with words and phrases.  Sometimes you're having an off day and sometimes it's the puzzle that's off, but if you get stuck, it's your puzzle and do whatever you feel like doing to get it done.  Coming back in a few minutes, an hour, or the next day, with a fresh start, can work wonders.  You know all of this, but you may need reminding!

Please don't give up. There were some puzzles this week that generated a lot of teeth-grinding for everyone, and for heaven's sake, don't take it personally.

We would miss you too much if you just walked away.

@Tim

Good point! "The answer came to me in a flash" = very quickly. "Fast" can be an adverb too, as in "I walk fast", but I agree, "quickly" would have been clearer.

@Tim "Fast" in that sense is called a flat or bare adverb; i.e. one that doesn't add -ly to its adjective form. If you want to go down a grammatical rabbit hole, there's this: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flat_adverb

@Steve L That was a fascinating read indeed! Interesting that flat adverbs went out of fashion because they were thought of as archaic, but now are back in fashion because of [who knows].

Unless I want to start saying "I work hardly" instead of "I work hard", I guess I can't complain.

@Mean Old Lady

We've both lived long enough to see substantial change in the English language, as it would in any 70-ish year period.  Just listen to recordings of FDR and you can immediately hear a difference that points to an earlier time.  

You'd have to switch to written language, but go back another similar period of time, to Dickens, then to the founding documents of the country, and so on, through Shakespeare, Chaucer and Beowulf, and you will see that English (or any language) doesn't stay static.

So a 70-year chunk of time is enough that things that were "correct" in our youth are odd or outdated now.  

"Winston tastes good, like a cigarette should."  Remember the foofaraw about the grammar in that slogan?  Today's youngs would be puzzled that there was an issue.

And back then, it was considered "wrong" for no good reason except that some prescriptivists didn't like it.

@Steve L
I disagree that it was 'for no good reason'. Clear writing reinforces clear thinking and sometimes just plain forces it. Having to figure out what snappy little phrase is modifying, while it lowers your delight as an author, increases the likelihood that your reader will get what you mean. Which is the goal, no?
Sgd.,
A prescriptivist swimming against the tide

@SBK Sorry, there's no way you can misconstrue the meaning of the Winston slogan. Sometimes, prescriptivists don't like something just because they perceive that it "sounds uneducated." But after a few generations of people ignoring the rule, it no longer sounds uneducated. It reminds me of Joe Pesci's question in the 1994 movie "With Honors," in which he, playing a self-described "bum" crashing a class at Harvard, asks the professor, " Which door do I leave from?" The professor tells him, "At Harvard, we don't end our sentences with prepositions," to which he replies, "Which door do I leave from, @$$hole?" If it takes 6 dressmakers 10 days to make 4 dresses, it‚Äôs no wonder that the garment industry has moved overseas.
@The X-Phile ok, the answer i got was 6.85 x 10^24 years give or take an aeon.
@Paul oops...correction...the above numbers were for 6 dress makers to make an octillion dresses....gotta divide that number by 166666 to solve for 1,000,000.
@Paul and when you run the math you get  41x10^19 years.  Which is a considerable time savings in the sweatshop.

@The X-Phile

The formula seems to me to be 

# dresses made = (# that 1 dress maker can make in 1 day)*(number of dress makers)*(number of days)

Call that equation (1).  # dresses = rate*(number makers)*(number days).

The first term (# that 1 dress maker can make in one day) is the rate of dresses made per maker per day.

That rate is easily found because we know

4 dresses = (# that 1 dress maker can make in one day)*(6 makers)*(10 days).

4 = (rate)(6)(10)

rate = 4/(6*10) = 1/15 dresses per maker per day.

Now we want the number of days needed for a million (10^^6) makers to make an octillion dresses (10^^27 in the so called "short scale")

We can rearrange Equation (1) to get the number of days:

(number of days) = (# dresses)/(rate*number makers)

so

(number of days) - (10^^27 dresses)/(1/15 dresses per maker per day)x(10^^6 dressmakers)

We want to make 10^^27 dresses so

(# of days) = 10^^27/((1/15)*10^^6) = 15 x 10^^21 day, or 1.5 x 10 ^22 days) 

My answer is 1.5x10^^22 days which exceeds the age of the universe by a factor on the order of a hundred billioni times.

Wendy,
The theme was consistent, it wasn't as rigid as you might have liked. In the themers, the first and second letters of either the first or last word -- and in the last themer, as clued -- both the first and last words -- are switched. The lack of rigidity added to the puzzling nature of the puzzle. Sorry it threw you.

@Wendy
I shared your reaction to the theme, that it was inconsistent - as you said because the letter reversals occurred in different places and also because the nature of the answers was different. e.g., a common phrase (lesser of two evils) versus a tv show (dancing with the stars) versus an item (cotillion dresses).

That said, my guess is that making this theme work at all was very difficult - and more consistency may well have not been possible.

But I do agree that the lack of consistency made the solve less satisfying for me, both during the solve and on completion. I was surprised to find that reaction not more widely shared, but it appears it was not.
